# @jsondb-cloud/cli - Complete LLM Reference

> The official CLI for jsondb.cloud — a hosted JSON document database.

jsondb.cloud is a cloud-hosted JSON document database. The CLI provides full
CRUD operations, import/export, schema management, versioning, webhooks, and
bulk operations from the terminal or CI pipelines.

Requires: Node.js >= 18

Package: @jsondb-cloud/cli
Binary name: jsondb
Repository: https://github.com/JsonDBCloud/cli
License: MIT

---

## Installation

### npm (recommended)

    npm install -g @jsondb-cloud/cli

### Homebrew (macOS/Linux)

    brew install jsondbcloud/tap/jsondb

### Standalone binaries

Download from https://github.com/JsonDBCloud/cli/releases

Platforms:
- macOS arm64 (Apple Silicon)
- macOS x64 (Intel)
- Linux x64
- Linux arm64

### Verify installation

    jsondb --version

---

## Configuration

### Credentials file

Location: ~/.config/jsondb/credentials.json
Permissions: 0o600 (read/write owner only)

Format:
    {
      "apiKey": "jdb_sk_live_...",
      "project": "default",
      "baseUrl": "https://api.jsondb.cloud"
    }

Created by `jsondb login`. Removed by `jsondb logout`.

### Environment variables

    JSONDB_API_KEY     API key (overrides credentials file)
    JSONDB_PROJECT     Project name (default if env set: "v1")
    JSONDB_NAMESPACE   Legacy alias for JSONDB_PROJECT
    JSONDB_BASE_URL    API base URL (default: "https://api.jsondb.cloud")

When JSONDB_API_KEY is set, all config is read from env vars only; the
credentials file is not read.

### Global flags

These flags apply to every command and override both env vars and config file:

    --api-key <key>    Use a specific API key
    --project <ns>     Target project (default: "default")
    --base-url <url>   API base URL
    --format <fmt>     Output format: json, raw, ndjson, table

### Precedence order (highest to lowest)

1. CLI flags (--api-key, --project, --base-url)
2. Environment variables (JSONDB_API_KEY, JSONDB_PROJECT, JSONDB_BASE_URL)
3. Credentials file (~/.config/jsondb/credentials.json)
4. Built-in defaults (project: "default", baseUrl: "https://api.jsondb.cloud")

### API URL construction

All API requests go to: {baseUrl}/{project}/{path}
Example: https://api.jsondb.cloud/default/users/usr_abc123

Authentication: Bearer token in Authorization header.

---

## Auth Commands

### login

Authenticate with jsondb.cloud and save credentials.

    jsondb login [--api-key <key>] [--project <ns>] [--base-url <url>]

Flags:
    --api-key <key>   API key (skips interactive prompt)
    --project <ns>    Default project (default: "default")
    --base-url <url>  API base URL (default: "https://api.jsondb.cloud")

Behavior:
- Without --api-key: prompts interactively "? Enter your API key: "
- Validates key starts with "jdb_sk_" prefix
- On invalid key: prints error with suggestion about jdb_sk_live_ or jdb_sk_test_ prefix
- Saves to ~/.config/jsondb/credentials.json with mode 0o600
- Creates ~/.config/jsondb/ directory if it does not exist

Output on success:
    OK: Authenticated successfully
      Project: default
      Key stored in /home/user/.config/jsondb/credentials.json

### logout

Remove stored credentials.

    jsondb logout

Behavior:
- Deletes ~/.config/jsondb/credentials.json
- Silently succeeds if file does not exist

Output:
    OK: Logged out. Credentials removed.

### whoami

Show current configuration.

    jsondb whoami

Behavior:
- Reads config (env vars or credentials file)
- If not authenticated: prints error and exits 1

Output:
      API Key: jdb_sk_live_abcd...wxyz
      Project: default
      Base URL: https://api.jsondb.cloud

The API key is masked: first 16 characters + "..." + last 4 characters.

---

## Document CRUD

Document paths use the format: {collection}/{documentId}
Example: users/usr_abc123

### get

Read a single document.

    jsondb get <path> [--format json|raw]

Arguments:
    path    Document path (collection/documentId)

Flags:
    --format <fmt>  "json" (default, pretty-printed) or "raw" (compact)

Example:
    jsondb get users/usr_abc123

Output: The full document JSON.

    {
      "_id": "usr_abc123",
      "name": "Alice",
      "email": "alice@example.com"
    }

With --format raw:
    {"_id":"usr_abc123","name":"Alice","email":"alice@example.com"}

Error: prints error message and exits 1.

### create

Create a new document in a collection.

    jsondb create <collection> [--file <file>] [--id <id>]

Arguments:
    collection   Target collection name

Flags:
    --file <file>   Read document JSON from file (otherwise reads stdin)
    --id <id>       Explicit document ID (otherwise server-generated)

Input: JSON object (from file or stdin).

Behavior:
- With --id: POSTs to {collection}/{id}
- Without --id: POSTs to {collection} (server assigns ID)
- Reads file synchronously or stdin via async iteration

Examples:
    jsondb create users --file user.json --id usr_custom_001

    echo '{"name":"Bob"}' | jsondb create users

Output:
    OK: Created usr_abc123 in users

Error on non-JSON input: JSON parse error.

### update

Full replacement of a document (PUT).

    jsondb update <path> [--file <file>]

Arguments:
    path   Document path (collection/documentId)

Flags:
    --file <file>   Read document JSON from file (otherwise reads stdin)

Behavior:
- Uses HTTP PUT — replaces the entire document
- Input must be a complete JSON object

Example:
    jsondb update users/usr_abc123 --file updated-user.json

Output:
    OK: Updated usr_abc123

### patch

Partial update of a document (PATCH).

    jsondb patch <path> [--file <file>]

Arguments:
    path   Document path (collection/documentId)

Flags:
    --file <file>   Read patch JSON from file (otherwise reads stdin)

Behavior:
- Uses HTTP PATCH — merges fields into the existing document
- Only specified fields are changed; unspecified fields remain

Example:
    echo '{"email":"new@example.com"}' | jsondb patch users/usr_abc123

Output:
    OK: Patched usr_abc123

### delete

Delete a document.

    jsondb delete <path>

Arguments:
    path   Document path (collection/documentId)

Behavior:
- Uses HTTP DELETE
- Treats HTTP 204 as success (no content)

Example:
    jsondb delete users/usr_abc123

Output:
    OK: Deleted users/usr_abc123

---

## Collection Commands

### collections

List all collection names in the project.

    jsondb collections

Behavior:
- Fetches up to 100 documents from the project root
- Extracts unique $collection field values
- Sorts alphabetically
- Prints one collection name per line

Output:
    orders
    products
    users

### documents

List documents in a collection.

    jsondb documents <collection> [--limit <n>] [--format json|raw]

Arguments:
    collection   Collection name

Flags:
    --limit <n>     Max documents to return (default: "20")
    --format <fmt>  "json" (pretty) or "raw" (compact)

Behavior:
- GETs {collection}?limit={n}
- Returns the full API response (typically includes data array and metadata)

Example:
    jsondb documents users --limit 5

Output: JSON array/object of documents.

---

## Import / Export

### push

Import documents from a local file into a collection.

    jsondb push <file> --to <collection> [--on-conflict fail|skip|overwrite]

Arguments:
    file   Local file path (.json, .csv, or .ndjson)

Flags (required):
    --to <collection>           Target collection name

Flags (optional):
    --on-conflict <strategy>    Conflict resolution: fail, skip, overwrite
                                Default: "fail"

Behavior:
- File must exist (checked before upload)
- Content-Type detected from file extension:
    .json   -> application/json
    .csv    -> text/csv
    .ndjson -> application/x-ndjson
- Posts raw file content to {collection}/_import?onConflict={strategy}
- In TTY mode, prints "Importing to {collection}..." before upload

Success output:
    OK: Imported 50 documents (48 created, 0 skipped, 2 failed, 0 overwritten)

If errors exist, shows first 10:
    WARN: 2 errors:
      - Index 3: Duplicate key error
      - Index 17: Validation failed
      ... and 0 more

Response shape from API:
    {
      "summary": {
        "total": 50,
        "created": 48,
        "skipped": 0,
        "failed": 2,
        "overwritten": 0
      },
      "errors": [
        { "index": 3, "error": { "message": "Duplicate key error" } }
      ]
    }

Example:
    jsondb push ./data/users.json --to users
    jsondb push ./data/products.csv --to products --on-conflict skip
    jsondb push ./logs.ndjson --to logs --on-conflict overwrite

### pull

Export documents from a collection.

    jsondb pull <collection> [--out <file>] [--format json|csv|ndjson] [--filter <field=value>]

Arguments:
    collection   Collection to export

Flags:
    --out <file>        Write to file (otherwise stdout)
    --format <fmt>      Export format: json (default), csv, ndjson
    --filter <expr>     Filter expression as field=value

Behavior:
- GETs {collection}/_export with Accept header based on format:
    json   -> application/json
    csv    -> text/csv
    ndjson -> application/x-ndjson
- Filter is parsed as "field=value" and sent as ?filter[field]=value
- Only one filter expression is supported
- With --out: writes content to file and prints document count
- Without --out: writes content directly to stdout

Output with --out:
    OK: Exported 25 documents to users.json

Document count calculation:
- json: parses and reads array length
- ndjson: counts non-empty lines
- csv: counts non-empty lines minus 1 (header row)

Examples:
    jsondb pull users --out users.json
    jsondb pull users --format csv --out users.csv
    jsondb pull orders --filter status=pending --format ndjson
    jsondb pull users | jq '.[].name'

---

## Schema Management

### schema get

Retrieve the JSON schema for a collection.

    jsondb schema get <collection>

Behavior:
- GETs {collection}/_schema
- On 404: prints "No schema set for collection '{collection}'" (not an error, exits 0)
- Prints the schema JSON (extracts .schema field if present, otherwise full response)

Example:
    jsondb schema get users

Output:
    {
      "type": "object",
      "required": ["name", "email"],
      "properties": {
        "name": { "type": "string" },
        "email": { "type": "string", "format": "email" }
      }
    }

### schema set

Set or replace the schema for a collection.

    jsondb schema set <collection> [--file <file>]

Flags:
    --file <file>   Schema JSON file (otherwise reads stdin)

Behavior:
- Uses HTTP PUT to {collection}/_schema
- Reads JSON schema from file or stdin
- Replaces any existing schema

Examples:
    jsondb schema set users --file user-schema.json
    cat schema.json | jsondb schema set users

Output:
    OK: Schema set for collection 'users'

### schema remove

Remove the schema from a collection.

    jsondb schema remove <collection>

Behavior:
- Uses HTTP DELETE on {collection}/_schema
- Documents are no longer validated after removal

Example:
    jsondb schema remove users

Output:
    OK: Schema removed from collection 'users'

---

## Version History

### versions list

List all versions of a document.

    jsondb versions list <collection> <id>

Arguments:
    collection   Collection name
    id           Document ID

Behavior:
- GETs {collection}/{id}/versions
- Displays a table with columns: Version, Action, Timestamp, Size
- Parses response from .versions, .data, or root array

Output:
    Version  Action   Timestamp             Size
    -------  ------   ---------             ----
    1        created  2025-01-15T10:30:00Z  245
    2        updated  2025-01-16T14:20:00Z  312
    3        updated  2025-01-17T09:00:00Z  298

If no versions: "No versions found."

### versions get

Retrieve a document at a specific version.

    jsondb versions get <collection> <id> <version>

Arguments:
    collection   Collection name
    id           Document ID
    version      Version number

Behavior:
- GETs {collection}/{id}/versions/{version}
- Returns the full document as it existed at that version

Example:
    jsondb versions get users usr_abc123 2

Output: JSON document at that version.

### versions diff

Show differences between two versions.

    jsondb versions diff <collection> <id> --from <n> --to <n>

Arguments:
    collection   Collection name
    id           Document ID

Flags (both required):
    --from <version>   Starting version number
    --to <version>     Ending version number

Behavior:
- Both --from and --to are required (enforced by commander requiredOption)
- GETs {collection}/{id}/versions/diff?from={n}&to={n}
- Returns a JSON diff object

Example:
    jsondb versions diff users usr_abc123 --from 1 --to 3

Output: JSON diff (format depends on server implementation).

### versions restore

Restore a document to a previous version.

    jsondb versions restore <collection> <id> <version>

Arguments:
    collection   Collection name
    id           Document ID
    version      Version number to restore to

Behavior:
- POSTs to {collection}/{id}/versions/{version}/restore
- Creates a new version with the restored content
- Prints success message and the restored document

Example:
    jsondb versions restore users usr_abc123 2

Output:
    OK: Restored usr_abc123 to version 2
    {
      "_id": "usr_abc123",
      "name": "Alice",
      "email": "alice@old-email.com"
    }

---

## Webhooks

### webhooks list

List webhooks for a collection.

    jsondb webhooks list <collection>

Behavior:
- GETs {collection}/_webhooks
- Displays table: ID, URL, Events, Status
- Events are displayed comma-separated

Output:
    ID          URL                              Events                    Status
    --          ---                              ------                    ------
    wh_abc123   https://example.com/hook         document.created          active
    wh_def456   https://example.com/all-events   document.created, document.updated  active

If no webhooks: "No webhooks found."

### webhooks create

Create a new webhook.

    jsondb webhooks create <collection> --url <url> --events <events> [--description <desc>] [--secret <secret>]

Arguments:
    collection   Collection name

Flags (required):
    --url <url>         Webhook endpoint URL
    --events <events>   Comma-separated event types

Flags (optional):
    --description <desc>   Human-readable description
    --secret <secret>      HMAC signing secret for payload verification

Valid event types:
    document.created
    document.updated
    document.deleted

Behavior:
- Events string is split by comma and trimmed
- POSTs to {collection}/_webhooks
- Returns the created webhook object

Example:
    jsondb webhooks create orders \
      --url https://example.com/webhook \
      --events document.created,document.updated \
      --description "Order notifications" \
      --secret my_webhook_secret_123

Output:
    OK: Created webhook wh_abc123
    {
      "_id": "wh_abc123",
      "url": "https://example.com/webhook",
      "events": ["document.created", "document.updated"],
      "description": "Order notifications",
      "status": "active"
    }

### webhooks get

Get webhook details and recent deliveries.

    jsondb webhooks get <collection> <id>

Arguments:
    collection   Collection name
    id           Webhook ID

Example:
    jsondb webhooks get orders wh_abc123

Output: Full webhook JSON including delivery history.

### webhooks update

Update an existing webhook.

    jsondb webhooks update <collection> <id> [--url <url>] [--events <events>] [--description <desc>] [--status active|disabled]

Arguments:
    collection   Collection name
    id           Webhook ID

Flags (all optional, but at least one required):
    --url <url>            New endpoint URL
    --events <events>      New comma-separated events
    --description <desc>   New description
    --status <status>      "active" or "disabled"

Behavior:
- Only provided fields are sent in the update (HTTP PUT)
- If no flags provided: prints error and exits 1
- Events string is split by comma and trimmed

Example:
    jsondb webhooks update orders wh_abc123 --status disabled
    jsondb webhooks update orders wh_abc123 --url https://new-url.com --events document.deleted

Output:
    OK: Updated webhook wh_abc123
    { ... updated webhook JSON ... }

### webhooks delete

Delete a webhook.

    jsondb webhooks delete <collection> <id>

Behavior:
- HTTP DELETE on {collection}/_webhooks/{id}
- HTTP 204 treated as success

Example:
    jsondb webhooks delete orders wh_abc123

Output:
    OK: Deleted webhook wh_abc123

### webhooks test

Send a test event to a webhook.

    jsondb webhooks test <collection> <id>

Behavior:
- POSTs to {collection}/_webhooks/{id}/test
- Returns the test delivery result

Example:
    jsondb webhooks test orders wh_abc123

Output:
    OK: Test event sent for webhook wh_abc123
    {
      "statusCode": 200,
      "duration": 142,
      "success": true
    }

---

## Utilities

### validate

Dry-run schema validation against a document.

    jsondb validate <collection> [--file <file>]

Arguments:
    collection   Collection name (must have a schema set)

Flags:
    --file <file>   Document JSON file (otherwise reads stdin synchronously)

Behavior:
- POSTs document to {collection}/_validate
- Does NOT create the document — validation only
- On HTTP 422: prints "Validation failed" + error details, exits 1
- On success: prints "Document is valid" + response

Examples:
    jsondb validate users --file user.json
    echo '{"name":"Bob"}' | jsondb validate users

Success output:
    OK: Document is valid
    { "valid": true }

Failure output (exit code 1):
    ERROR: Validation failed
    {
      "error": {
        "message": "Validation failed",
        "details": [
          { "field": "email", "message": "required field missing" }
        ]
      }
    }

### count

Count documents in a collection, optionally filtered.

    jsondb count <collection> [--filter <expr...>]

Arguments:
    collection   Collection name

Flags:
    --filter <expr...>   One or more filter expressions (field=value)
                         Multiple --filter flags allowed (variadic)

Behavior:
- GETs {collection}?count=true with filter query params
- Filters are appended as &filter[field]=value
- Supports operator syntax: field[op]=value (e.g., status[ne]=deleted)
- Invalid filters (no = sign): prints error and exits 1
- Extracts count from .count, .meta.total, or raw response

Examples:
    jsondb count users
    jsondb count orders --filter status=pending
    jsondb count orders --filter status=pending --filter total[gte]=100

Output: A single number on stdout.
    42

### bulk

Execute bulk operations from a JSON array.

    jsondb bulk <collection> [--file <file>]

Arguments:
    collection   Collection name

Flags:
    --file <file>   Operations JSON file (otherwise reads stdin synchronously)

Behavior:
- Input must be a JSON array of operation objects
- If input is not an array: prints "Bulk operations must be a JSON array" and exits 1
- POSTs to {collection}/_bulk
- Returns the bulk operation results

Example input (operations array):
    [
      { "op": "create", "data": { "name": "Alice" } },
      { "op": "update", "id": "usr_abc123", "data": { "name": "Alice Updated" } },
      { "op": "delete", "id": "usr_old001" }
    ]

Example:
    jsondb bulk users --file operations.json
    cat ops.json | jsondb bulk users

Output:
    OK: Bulk operation completed
    {
      "results": [
        { "op": "create", "success": true, "_id": "usr_new001" },
        { "op": "update", "success": true, "_id": "usr_abc123" },
        { "op": "delete", "success": true, "_id": "usr_old001" }
      ]
    }

---

## API Key Management

### keys list

List API keys for the account.

    jsondb keys list

Behavior:
- GETs /api/keys (raw path, not project-scoped)
- Displays table: NAME, HINT, SCOPE, PROJECT, STATUS, CREATED
- Hint is displayed as "...{last4chars}"

Output:
    NAME           HINT         SCOPE       PROJECT   STATUS  CREATED
    ----           ----         -----       -------   ------  -------
    Production     ...a1b2      read-write  default   active  1/15/2025
    Read-only      ...c3d4      read-only   default   active  2/1/2025

If no keys: "No API keys found."

### keys create

Create a new API key.

    jsondb keys create [--name <name>] [--scope <scope>] [--project <ns>]

Flags:
    --name <name>      Key name (default: "CLI-generated key")
    --scope <scope>    Scope: read-only, read-write (default: "read-write")
    --project <ns>     Target project (default: "default")

NOTE: Key creation requires dashboard authentication. The CLI redirects to:
https://jsondb.cloud/dashboard/api-keys

The CLI prints an error and exits 1:
    ERROR: Key creation requires dashboard authentication. Use the web
    dashboard at https://jsondb.cloud/dashboard/api-keys

### keys revoke

Revoke an API key.

    jsondb keys revoke <id>

NOTE: Key revocation requires dashboard authentication. The CLI redirects to:
https://jsondb.cloud/dashboard/api-keys

The CLI prints an error and exits 1:
    ERROR: Key revocation requires dashboard authentication. Use the web
    dashboard at https://jsondb.cloud/dashboard/api-keys

---

## Error Handling

### Exit codes

- 0: Success
- 1: Any error (auth, validation, API, input parsing)

### Error message format

TTY (interactive terminal):
    [red] X Error: <message>
      <suggestion if provided>

Non-TTY (piped/scripted):
    ERROR: <message>
    <suggestion if provided>

### Common error patterns

Authentication missing:
    ERROR: Not authenticated
    Run `jsondb login` to authenticate, or pass --api-key

Invalid API key format:
    ERROR: Invalid API key format
    API keys start with 'jdb_sk_live_' or 'jdb_sk_test_'

API error response shape:
    {
      "error": {
        "message": "Document not found"
      }
    }

The CLI extracts .error.message from API responses. If parsing fails, it
falls back to "Request failed with status {statusCode}".

JSON parse errors: thrown when stdin or file input is not valid JSON.

### Status message prefixes

TTY mode:
    [green checkmark] <message>     Success
    [red X] Error: <message>        Error
    [yellow warning] <message>      Warning

Non-TTY mode:
    OK: <message>       Success
    ERROR: <message>    Error
    WARN: <message>     Warning

---

## Output Formats

### JSON output

TTY (interactive):
- Pretty-printed with 2-space indentation
- JSON.stringify(data, null, 2)

Non-TTY (piped) or --format raw:
- Compact single-line JSON
- JSON.stringify(data)

### Table output

Used by: versions list, webhooks list, keys list

Format:
- Headers in UPPERCASE
- Columns padded to widest value
- Separator line of dashes between header and data
- Columns separated by two spaces

### Stdout vs stderr

- Success messages: stdout (console.log)
- Error messages: stderr (console.error)
- Document data: stdout (console.log)
- Warnings: stdout (console.log)

---

## Common Workflows

### Getting started

    # 1. Install
    npm install -g @jsondb-cloud/cli

    # 2. Authenticate
    jsondb login
    # Enter API key when prompted: jdb_sk_live_...

    # 3. Verify
    jsondb whoami

    # 4. Create a document
    echo '{"name":"Alice","email":"alice@example.com"}' | jsondb create users

    # 5. Read it back
    jsondb get users/usr_abc123

    # 6. List collections
    jsondb collections

### Import/export workflow

    # Import from JSON
    jsondb push ./seed-data/users.json --to users

    # Import CSV, skip duplicates
    jsondb push ./data/products.csv --to products --on-conflict skip

    # Export to file
    jsondb pull users --out backup/users.json

    # Export filtered data as CSV
    jsondb pull orders --filter status=shipped --format csv --out shipped.csv

    # Export to stdout and pipe to jq
    jsondb pull users | jq '.[].email'

### Schema enforcement workflow

    # 1. Define schema
    cat > user-schema.json << 'EOF'
    {
      "type": "object",
      "required": ["name", "email"],
      "properties": {
        "name": { "type": "string", "minLength": 1 },
        "email": { "type": "string", "format": "email" }
      },
      "additionalProperties": false
    }
    EOF

    # 2. Apply schema
    jsondb schema set users --file user-schema.json

    # 3. Validate before creating (dry run)
    echo '{"name":"Bob"}' | jsondb validate users
    # ERROR: Validation failed (missing email)

    # 4. Fix and validate
    echo '{"name":"Bob","email":"bob@example.com"}' | jsondb validate users
    # OK: Document is valid

    # 5. Create the document
    echo '{"name":"Bob","email":"bob@example.com"}' | jsondb create users

    # 6. Check current schema
    jsondb schema get users

    # 7. Remove schema if no longer needed
    jsondb schema remove users

### Version management workflow

    # List versions of a document
    jsondb versions list users usr_abc123

    # View document at a specific version
    jsondb versions get users usr_abc123 1

    # Compare versions
    jsondb versions diff users usr_abc123 --from 1 --to 3

    # Restore to a previous version
    jsondb versions restore users usr_abc123 2

### Webhook workflow

    # Create a webhook for new orders
    jsondb webhooks create orders \
      --url https://api.example.com/hooks/orders \
      --events document.created,document.updated \
      --description "New order notifications" \
      --secret whsec_my_signing_secret

    # List webhooks
    jsondb webhooks list orders

    # Test the webhook
    jsondb webhooks test orders wh_abc123

    # Disable temporarily
    jsondb webhooks update orders wh_abc123 --status disabled

    # Re-enable
    jsondb webhooks update orders wh_abc123 --status active

    # Delete when no longer needed
    jsondb webhooks delete orders wh_abc123

### CI/CD pipeline usage

    # Use environment variables (no interactive login)
    export JSONDB_API_KEY=jdb_sk_live_...
    export JSONDB_PROJECT=production

    # Or use flags
    jsondb push ./data/seed.json --to users --api-key jdb_sk_live_... --project production

    # Count documents to verify import
    jsondb count users

    # Export for backup
    jsondb pull users --out /backups/users-$(date +%Y%m%d).json

### Scripting with pipes

    # Create document from pipe
    curl -s https://api.example.com/user/1 | jsondb create users

    # Patch from computed JSON
    echo '{"lastLogin":"2025-01-15T10:00:00Z"}' | jsondb patch users/usr_abc123

    # Bulk operations from generated input
    cat operations.json | jsondb bulk users

    # Export and transform
    jsondb pull users --format ndjson | while read -r line; do
      echo "$line" | jq '{name: .name, email: .email}'
    done

---

## Complete Command Reference (quick lookup)

    jsondb login [--api-key] [--project] [--base-url]
    jsondb logout
    jsondb whoami

    jsondb get <path> [--format json|raw]
    jsondb create <collection> [--file] [--id]
    jsondb update <path> [--file]
    jsondb patch <path> [--file]
    jsondb delete <path>

    jsondb collections
    jsondb documents <collection> [--limit] [--format json|raw]

    jsondb push <file> --to <collection> [--on-conflict fail|skip|overwrite]
    jsondb pull <collection> [--out] [--format json|csv|ndjson] [--filter]

    jsondb schema get <collection>
    jsondb schema set <collection> [--file]
    jsondb schema remove <collection>

    jsondb versions list <collection> <id>
    jsondb versions get <collection> <id> <version>
    jsondb versions diff <collection> <id> --from <n> --to <n>
    jsondb versions restore <collection> <id> <version>

    jsondb webhooks list <collection>
    jsondb webhooks create <collection> --url <url> --events <events> [--description] [--secret]
    jsondb webhooks get <collection> <id>
    jsondb webhooks update <collection> <id> [--url] [--events] [--description] [--status]
    jsondb webhooks delete <collection> <id>
    jsondb webhooks test <collection> <id>

    jsondb validate <collection> [--file]
    jsondb count <collection> [--filter <expr...>]
    jsondb bulk <collection> [--file]

    jsondb keys list
    jsondb keys create [--name] [--scope] [--project]  (dashboard only)
    jsondb keys revoke <id>                            (dashboard only)

---

## Links

- Docs: https://jsondb.cloud/docs/cli
- npm: https://www.npmjs.com/package/@jsondb-cloud/cli
- GitHub: https://github.com/JsonDBCloud/cli
- Dashboard: https://jsondb.cloud/dashboard

## Related Packages

- `@jsondb-cloud/client` — JavaScript/TypeScript SDK — https://www.npmjs.com/package/@jsondb-cloud/client
- `@jsondb-cloud/mcp` — MCP server for AI agents — https://www.npmjs.com/package/@jsondb-cloud/mcp
- `jsondb-cloud` (PyPI) — Python SDK — https://pypi.org/project/jsondb-cloud/
